alternateName: The unusual frequency domain of French lexemes

distribution.name: archive.zip
distribution.description: Archive containing all the contents of the rare french words dataset

distribution.name: french_uncommon_words.csv
distribution.description:
## File format & encoding  

- **Format**: Comma-Separated Values (CSV)
- **Encoding**: UTF-8 (no BOM)
- **Line endings**: Unix-style (LF)
- **Quote character**: `"` (double-quote)
- **Escape character**: None

## Column schema  
| Column name               | Type     | Description                                                                                                                     | Allowed values / Notes                                                     |
|---------------------------|----------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **word**                  | string   | The inflected or citation form of the entry.                                                                                    | Lowercase, Unicode letters & diacritics, no leading/trailing spaces.       |
| **gender**                | 1 char. enum (string)   | Gender of the word.                                                                                    | `m` = masculine | `f` = feminine | blank = missing        |
| **base_form**             | string   | Lemma or dictionary headword (infinitive, singular masculine, etc.).                                                           | Same constraints as **word**.                                              |
| **phonological_transcription**| string   | ASCII transcription of pronunciation.                                                                    | ASCII symbols only. No International Phonetic Alphabet symbols.                                               |
| **frequency_index**       | float  | A weighted average synthetic frequency index indicating relative (un)commonness in a reference corpus. Frequencies are per million occurences.                           | `0.002` ≤ value ≤ `0.04`                                  |
| **definitions**           | string   | One or more senses separated by | (the pipe character).                                                                  | Wrap entire field in quotes if it contains commas or |.             |

## Sample header & row

```csv
word,gender,base_form,phonological_transcription,frequency_index,definitions
abaca,m,abaca,abaka,0.002,"Bananier des Philippines de la famille des musacées… | Fibre textile tirée du bananier…"
```

## Field-by-Field details

- **word**
  - What: word form as used in text or as citation form.
  - Why: lookup and matching against corpora.
  - Validation: non-empty; unicode letters, hyphens, apostrophes only.

- **gender**
  - What: gender (m/f).
  - Why: grammar‐sensitive applications.
  - Validation: exactly `m`, `f`, or blank.

- **base_form**
  - What: word’s canonical base form (lemma).
  - Why: lemmatization and grouping inflected variants.
  - Validation: same as word.

- **phonological_transcription**
  - What: Lexique3.83 transcription ("phon" field)
  - Why: pronunciation modeling.
  - Validation: no delimiters.
  > This isn’t IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet) but a simplified, ASCII-based “respelling”. For example: “aboRiZEn” tells you to say /a.bɔ.ʁi.ʒɛn/

- **frequency_index**
  - What: decimals [`0.002–0.4`] reflecting corpus frequency.
  - Why: rank/filter by commonness.
  - Validation: numeric, 0.002 ≤ value ≤ 0.4

- **definitions**
  - What: one or more senses separated by `|`.
  - Why: human-readable semantics.
  - Validation: quote entire field if it contains commas or |.

## Exploratory data analysis


## Usage examples

Select feminine nouns:

```python
fem_nouns = df[(df.gender == "f")]
```

List rare words:
```python
# Compute the 10th percentile
cutoff = df["frequency_index"].quantile(0.10)

# Select the bottom decile
rare_decile = df[df["frequency_index"] <= cutoff]
print(f"Frequency cutoff for bottom decile: {cutoff:.6f}")
print(f"Number of rare entries: {len(rare_decile)}")
```

field.name: word
field.description: The word or term being defined.

field.name: base_form
field.description: The base form or lemma of the word, often used in linguistic analysis.

field.name: phonological_transcription
field.description: An ASCII based phonological transcription (not International Phonetic Alphabet).

field.name: frequency_index
field.description: Weighted average of several indexes related to frequencies. Frequencies are per million occurences.

field.name: definitions
field.description: One or more senses separated by | (the pipe character).

| **phonological_transcription**| string   | ASCII transcription of pronunciation.                                                                    | ASCII symbols only. No International Phonetic Alphabet symbols.                                               |
| **frequency_index**       | float  | A weighted average synthetic frequency index indicating relative (un)commonness in a reference corpus. Frequencies are per million occurences.                           | `0.002` ≤ value ≤ `0.04`                                  |

  - Validation: non-empty; unicode letters, hyphens, apostrophes only.

name: rare french words
description:
![Banner Image](https://www.googleapis.com/download/storage/v1/b/kaggle-user-content/o/inbox%2F27942110%2Fb9ef995049433e9bfbba309927685629%2Fdoisneau_school.jpg?generation=1753121835858186&alt=media "Children at school by Doisneau.")
Focused or daydreaming? I think he is performing mental calculations of vector embeddings. *Photograph by R. Doisneau (école de la rue Buffon in Paris,1956).* ## Overview This dataset is a tabular collection of **9351 uncommon French words** annotated with: - their gender - base form (lemma) - phonological transcription - a frequency index - one or more dictionary definitions. Designed for NLP research, lexicography, language‐learning tools, and corpus-based studies. ## Genesis > This dataset is an offspring of the [dailyword project](https://github.com/brooks-code/fuzzy-carnival). A linux package that aims at enabling a new rare word to be discovered, once a day, straight from your terminal (in an unobtrusive fashion). To achieve this, I've had to cross-reference two datasets (more details in the related sources section). --- ## Reproducibility If you are interested in reproducing this dataset of your own or expand it. You will find details about its building on [GitHub](https://github.com/brooks-code/fuzzy-carnival/blob/main/README.md) in the processing section and folder. ## Versioning & changelog - v1.0.0 – July 2025 - Initial release - v1.0.1 – October 2025 - Corrected feature name (phonetic to phonological) ## Related sources Special **thanks** to the community for providing these valuable datasets. **Datasets:** - Lexique 3 ([version 3.83](http://www.lexique.org/databases/Lexique383/Lexique383.tsv)) provided valuable insights about french words frequencies. More information [is available here](http://www.lexique.org/databases/Lexique383/Manuel_Lexique.3.pdf) (pdf, in french). ```markdown @article{New2001, author = {New, B. and Pallier, C. and Ferrand, L. and Matos, R.}, title = {Une base de données lexicales du français contemporain sur internet: LEXIQUE}, journal = {L'Année Psychologique}, volume = {101}, pages = {447-462}, year = {2001}, url = {http://www.lexique.org} } @article{New2004, author = {New, B. and Pallier, C. and Brysbaert, M. and Ferrand, L.}, title = {Lexique 2 : A New French Lexical Database}, journal = {Behavior Research Methods, Instruments, & Computers}, volume = {36}, number = {3}, pages = {516-524}, year = {2004} } ``` - [Kartmaan's](https://github.com/Kartmaan/french-language-tools) french wiktionary [CSV dump](https://github.com/Kartmaan/french-language-tools/blob/master/files/dico.csv). Available on [Kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/kartmaan/dictionnaire-francais) as well. ## License Licensed under the CC0 license.
